reviews.review_title: Encanto gone dark with unfair ending
reviews.content: I'm impressed by the young cast, the plot was intriguing but the treatment to some of the characters is heavily unjust.Like, what the hell was Benjamin's motive to even kill his mom? And his own death doesn't change anything for Aisha's poor mom who will serve a long prison time, yet hate herself for "killing" Aisha.The story would've been better if Ida herself had a power and if there was a real showdown between the kids in the playground so everybody could see that superpowers are real. In that case Aisha's mom and the man who "killed" the teen bully would be free again.

reviews.review_title: The Innoncents don't make any claim
reviews.content:
Rare enough are the movies presenting children is such a realistic manner, played by very natural young actors not to recognize this very merit of The Innocents. And the director can be proud of his paediatrician skills as the world he place his little actors in is dark and uncomfortable.Childhood fits right in a fantastic frame: a child's mind is an open door to the irrationnal made rational; it is a smooth, efficient way to install a paradoxal situation that is the fabric of horror cinema.I have yet a problem with this film: either the story is too simple to bear any relevance (the temptation for evil at a very early age is a hackneyed subject among all) and even to become a justification for a feature film, or it has an underlying message, one about integration and the radicalization of ill-integrated young people raised by single mothers in suburban disctricts; you see where this leads us...
If the film delivers this kind of political subtext, it raises other dubious questions. Like why are the heroines white blonde girls and the evil one is a dark-skinned boy...
As it is, walking on a frail line between ethics, needs, frustration, friendship, alienation, differences, The Innoncents don't make any claim, the film holds its mystery and that is already a precious virtue.

reviews.review_title: Maybe I need to speak Norwegian?
reviews.content: I watched this without subtitles nor dubbed. Honestly, I didn't need to understand anything they were saying.Maybe it would have been better if I had?The first half kind of lagged, wondering where this was going. Then it became obvious.It's Damien from the Omen!Actually my mind started to think more about the ethnically diverse people in the apartments and the political situation in Norway with immigrants. Or is it Sweden? And how the villain just happened to be, well, not ethnically a Norwegian.And how maybe this film had a political motivation?Its' hard for me to be too critical without even knowing what was said. The movie wasn't terribly original otherwise.

Reminds me of Katsuhiro Otomo's DOMU...changed the antagonist & protagonist backstory a bit but still in some housing project venue. Can you smell what the rock is cooking? Life is either a daring adventure or nothing at all.

reviews.review_title: Do you like slow entertainment, kids and somwhat disturbing scenes?
reviews.content: For starters I just want to say that this kind of movie really reminded me of "The Blair Witch Project".The kind of "horror" that put a lot of work in to the introduction, and never really makes any progress until towards the ending.Just as you start thinking, "maybe something is about to happen", just sit down and relax, because no, that something will never come.To sum it all up, this is more psychological than horror really. There is nothing scary, and to actually call this a horror movie is a fault.This movie is also for those that like to sit still and really take their time trying to understand what kinds of feelings the author wants you to capture.

This movie is real, from a real place (the place I grew up, Romsaas Oslo Norway). What's depicted in the movie is nothing compared to all the stuff that has happened in that place in the last 50 years. Brilliant movie, more real than what even the director thought really was for real.

The performance of the children was superb and I hope that Rakel Lenora Flottum will have a great career. However, the story was simply not convincing. The "horror" elements were quite cheap, especially the cellar scene. There were many scenes/shots that were just unpleasant to watch, but were not elaborate in their essence.I liked the bananas.

Although there is not much dialogue, but every scene tells a story. Each expression describes an emotion that the viewer can feel. I love how they taken the pic, perfect cinematography. But the most hanging from this movie is scene where Ben's mother died and what's happen next.This movie was tell you so much about children's dark side. Unstable times that Experienced by the children. This movie was describe about the reality of children that cannot handle the big power.This is just scared me when they show their powers. Even not perfect story, but I'm really appreciate this movie's storyline. I'm enjoyed.

Nordic horror films really have no filter when it comes to violence especially involving children, something that is not seen in Hollywood or Asian films. Thus probably why there is no rating for the film.This is a film centered around a group of children who slowly discover that they have supernatural abilities and their playing around with these powers leads to some dark events. These powers give some of these children the ability to let out and vent their internal struggles growing up in abusive situations with some devastating consequences. While others use their powers to help others. There is sort of a theme about how the parents treat their kids can affect the children's behaviour. As the kids play around with their powers and each other, there are some disturbing and mean things that kids do to each other which may very well happen in real life. Yet there are limits to how far one can go and the film shows that while kids may be cruel they do have a sense of what is wrong and right when it crosses a line. There are some racist undertones with the choice of the cast depicting certain characters and actions.Apart from the disturbing scenes, this film had some excellent cinematography which really puts you in in the children's (who are the main actors) shoes. The zooming out shots are especially effective at giving a bird's eye view of the world.Overall, would give it a 6.7/10 (rating system only allows whole numbers) for excellent acting by the children and vivid imagery. If they would have left out some of the violent depictions then it would have deserved a higher rating. The writer and director (same person), Eskil Vogt, certainly has some sick ideas that they wished to do as kids.

It was so tortureously slow. Thought it was building up to something cool but it was terribly anti-climatic. Incredibly boring and a waste of time. Don't even bother watching it.I've noticed nordic films have this tendency to really drag things out and this movie does precisely that. It's like the directors have a worthless idea and just decide to push through anyway. Some ideas are better left unpursued, and this was one of those.The entire movie had maybe three cool scenes that were actually creepy/scary, the rest is just a bunch of children being awful to each other and a poor cat. I wish I hadn't spent so much time of my day on this incredibly boring movie.

Dear Makers of "De uskyldige",
this movie is a masterpiece. The acting of these children is amazing! Directing, cinematography, score... flawless.But, Bertrand Russell, be my witness! I will never forgive you for showing me that specific kind of explicit violence against children without putting a big, fat trigger warning on that movie! I love movies, I love the genre, I am used to some graphic stuff, but a lousy "Horror" label, in this case, is by far not enough for your special cruelties. Takk for ingenting!
